course.subject: COMP
course.name: Independent Work
course.description: Independent studies or projects under the directed guidance of a faculty member on a computer science topic. A written report, presentation, and/or an examination are required. Enrollment in the course requires prior approval of the course instructor, and credits assigned depend on the workload. May be repeated for credits.

reviews.author: Siddarth
reviews.comment_content:
Only one project on a Finance related topic that you work on your own throughout the semester, and you must write a report on it.

Just make sure to make suitable progress within every 2 weeks, and try to propose a creative idea. Then both you and the professor will enjoy the process.

The best part is that your work will get posted on the professor's website!
reviews.comment_teaching: You are only supervsied with the professor, and have a meeting every 2 weeks. No taught work.
reviews.comment_grading:
Excellent grading, so long as you propose a creative idea and show significant work in implementing the solution, and then explain it well in the essay you will get AT LEAST an A.

I myself was able to get an A+ after proposing an idea that the professor liked, and was invited to do the course for another semester.
reviews.comment_workload: I would consider it like doing a mini PA every 2 weeks. So if you find Coding Projects difficult, and are not self motivated DO NOT DO THIS COURSE. But if you are like me and enjoy coding projects, and don't need supervision to do work then you will have a wonderful experience.

reviews.author: cryptojet
reviews.title: This is the best course in HKUST
reviews.comment_content: Rossiter is the best professor at HKUST. The course is decided for students to create the project in their mind. Therefore, there won't be much guidance.
reviews.comment_teaching: There will not be much teaching. Therefore, you have to work on your own. It is the purpose of this course.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very very good. I get an A+ with effort. The grading is directly proportional to the effort you spend. If you work hard, you get good grades.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload really depends on rather you want to do more or not. I suggest to do more so that you can get a good grade.

reviews.author: YetAnotherAdi
reviews.title: Definitely take this course if you are offered it
reviews.comment_content:
Pick a topic that combines finance and coding. There are some really creative examples you can find at https://cse.hkust.edu.hk/~rossiter/#ug_student_projects (including mine!).

As you can see on the site, you have a lot of freedom in what you can pick, from using AI to generate NFT artwork to developing trading algorithms based on any creative strategy you can come up with.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not really any teaching involved.

Professor was available whenever I needed for a quick video call to go over my progress and ask for advice whether on code libraries, project strategies, or report writing tips.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good.
As long as you can show you're putting in effort, you will receive a good grade. You will have checkups every other week or so to confirm that you are keeping on track, keep at a good progress and you will be fine.

YOUR PROJECT DOES NOT NEED TO BE PROFITABLE.

The purpose is to have a good, interesting research project that is creative and supported with a good report outlining your findings, generally only the good reports are uploaded to Professor Rossiter's page so you can take a look at them for some good examples.

Because of this, even though my strategy for example - while profitable - performed worse than a Buy & Hold strategy, I received an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
As long as you manage your time well you will be fine, the regular checks with the professor should keep you on track but as this is an independent study course - some discipline is required.

Note that it is flexible, I had very little progress leading up to and around midterms/finals and that was fine/understandable.

I strongly recommend writing and planning out parts of the report early on in the semester as you are writing instead of leaving it until the last second.

reviews.author: Waylon
reviews.comment_content: Independent studies or projects under the directed guidance of a faculty member on a computer science topic. A written report, presentation, and/or an examination are required.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A nice professor!

I really enjoyed listening to Rossiter's lecture, his English is easy to understand, and his lectures are always interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: It is a project-orientated course, so the grade is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy I think.
I did a lot of research and read a lot of papers at the beginning. But the later the workload is acceptable.

reviews.author: 2ijr1ohui3wbehr
reviews.title: shit
reviews.comment_content:
Many people experience a whirlwind of emo-
tions as they enter college. You may be excited to move out and begin a life on your own, as well as meet
new people and try new activities. However, it is perfectly natural to be a bit
nervous, too, as college is a completely new experience and you may feel pressure to
choose a course of study. Towards an Inclusive Community of Undergraduate Physicists
(TiCuP) and Princeton Society of Physics Students (PSPS) have come together to demystify course selection and the physics and astrophysics majors. Drawing on the wisdom and experi- ence of past, current, and prospective majors, we are here to help you overcome any confusion or academic unsureness and guide you through your first years at Princeton.
After working hard in high school, it may seem like the only viable path to a challenging major such as physics or astrophysics is to take the hardest, most advanced courses as early as possible. The goal of
this guide is to convince you that this is not the case. Just as there are a plethora of research fields within physics and astrophysics (atomic physics, cosmology, biophysics, nanotechnology, etc.), there are a plethora of ways to pursue the physics and astrophysics majors. While your junior and senior years give you the opportunity to explore your research interests, your first year allows you to choose your fundamental physics base. The important thing to take away is this:
reviews.comment_teaching: When look- ing through courses, don’t worry about making the “right” choice. Invest some time in thinking about your courses, but remember that your first year is not going to make or break your Princeton career; there are plenty of students that begin in one field, and, after their first year, decide to move somewhere else. The liberal arts system ensures that your first two years are open to
reviews.comment_grading:
It is more important to get a solid understanding of physics than to push oneself to take a course that is too advanced.
We all come from different schools, states, and countries, and therefore we approach our studies with differ- ent backgrounds and perspectives. With this in mind, it doesn’t make sense to compare yourself to your peers; rather, it is more important to ensure that you build the unique foundation that you need to be successful.
reviews.comment_workload: To figure out which courses you want to take, think about which subjects most interest you. If you are read- ing this guide, then your interests probably involve some combination of physics, astrophysics, and math, although they may also involve chemistry, biology, poetry, music, or any number of other things. When look- ing through courses, don’t worry about making the “right” choice. Invest some time in thinking about your courses, but remember that your first year is not going to make or break your Princeton career; there are plenty of students that begin in one field, and, after their first year, decide to move somewhere else. The liberal arts system ensures that your first two years are open to
